Tel.: +98 25 32850953; fax: +98 25 32103595. Graphical abstract This paper reports the synthesis and use of TiO2@Pd nanoparticles, as reusable catalysts for Heck coupling reaction under ligand-free conditions. This method has the advantages of high yields, elimination of ligand and homogeneous catalysts, simple methodology and easy work up. Interestingly, the novel catalyst could be recovered in a facile manner from the reaction mixture and recycled several times without any significant loss in activity. The catalyst was characterized by SEM, EDS and UV–vis spectroscopy. Experimental absorbance spectra compared with results from the Mie theory. Keywords TiO2@Pd nanoparticles Heck coupling Heterogeneous catalyst Optical properties 1 Introduction The palladium-catalyzed arylation of alkenes, the Heck reaction, provides a very useful route for forming new CC bonds at an unsubstituted vinylic position and has found wide application in the preparation of materials, natural products, bioactive compounds and organic synthesis [1,2]. The Heck reaction has mostly been catalyzed by palladium (1–5% mole) complexes as pre-catalyst or palladium complexes combined with ligands such as phosphorus ligands [3], N-heterocyclic carbenes [4], P,O based ligands [5], thiosemicarbazones [6] and bis(thiourea) ligands [7] in organic solvents under homogeneous conditions. However, each of these methods suffer from different drawbacks such as employing expensive, toxic and hazardous reagent and ligands, tedious work-ups, low yields, environmental pollution caused by formation of side products [1–7]. Unfortunately, the efficient separation and subsequent recycling of homogeneous Pd catalysts remains a scientific challenge and result in environmental problems. However, use of homogeneous palladium catalysts is uneconomic for large-scale preparations in the laboratory and for industrial production. Therefore, it is desirable to develop cheaper and environmentally benign heterogeneous catalytic systems. Nanotechnology is emerging as a cutting edge technology interdisciplinary with biology, chemistry and material science. Metal nanoparticles have been used widely in many applications in different fields, such as catalysis, photonics and electronics. Due to a higher available catalytic surface, heterogeneous catalysts are more and more used in the form of nanoparticles. Thus, we decided to concentrate on developing an efficient and heterogeneous Pd catalyst that is air and moisture stable and highly active. Recently, a variety of Pd nanoparticles amenable for easy separation and recovery have been synthesized and applied as heterogeneous catalysts to a range of chemical reactions. We recently published synthesis of heterogeneous Pd nanoparticles and their application in organic synthesis [8,9]. In the course of our researches on the applications of heterogeneous catalysts [10–17], herein we now report a new, simple and inexpensive protocol for the preparation of TiO2@Pd nanoparticles by simple drop drying deposition of palladium on surface of TiO2 nanoparticles. The catalyst is heterogeneous and reusable, which provides an advantage over the homogeneous Pd-catalyst. To the best of our knowledge, no examples of synthesis of TiO2@Pd by dropping PdCl2 solution onto TiO2 nanoparticles films have been reported. In the next step, we hereby describe the development of TiO2@Pd nanoparticles as a novel and stable heterogeneous catalyst for Heck coupling reaction under ligand-free conditions (Scheme 1 ). During this study, we also introduce the effective medium optical constant for decorated nanoparticles (TiO2 nanoparticles decorated by Pd nanoparticles) thin films by comparing the experimental data and calculation results in the visible range. Mie theory and these effective optical constants were used for calculation of extinction cross section of dispersed above nanostructures in water. Our simulation results show that this approach can be used for prediction of optical spectra of decorated nanoparticles. 2 Experimental 2.1 Instruments and reagents All reagents were purchased from the Merck and Aldrich chemical companies and used without further purification. Products were characterized by different spectroscopic methods (FT-IR and 1H NMR spectra), elemental analysis (CHN) and melting points. The NMR spectra were recorded in CDCl3 or DMSO-d 6 . 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance DRX 300MHz instrument. The chemical shifts (δ) are reported in ppm relative to the TMS as internal standard. J values are given in Hz. IR (KBr) spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer 781 spectrophotometer. Melting points were taken in open capillary tubes with a BUCHI 510 melting point apparatus and were uncorrected. The elemental analysis was performed using Heraeus CHN-O-Rapid analyzer. TLC was performed on silica gel polygram SIL G/UV 254 plates. Morphology and particle dispersion was investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Cam scan MV2300). The chemical composition of the prepared nanostructures was measured by EDS performed in SEM. UV–vis spectral analysis was recorded on a double-beam spectrophotometer (Hitachi, U-2900). The loading content of Pd in the catalysts was determined by ICP-AES (VISTAMPX). 2.2 Preparation of TiO2@Pd nanoparticles The titania utilized in this study was a commercially available dry powder TiO2 nanoparticles (Plasmachem GmbH) of pure anatase crystalline structure with nominal 40nm particle size. TiO2@Pd nanoparticles were prepared by one-pot process. Deposition of Pd on surface of TiO2 nanoparticles was accomplished via a simple drop-drying process by dropping 50mL PdCl2 solution onto 50mL of aqueous solution of TiO2 (0.5g in 100mL). In order to extract the dispersed nanoparticles, the solution was centrifuged several times, dispersed on a glass substrate and drying them at room temperature. The PdCl2 solution was prepared by ultrasonically solving a 0.02g PdCl2 powder (5N), 99.9mL DI water and 0.1mL HCl. 2.3 Preparation of (E)-1,2-diphenylethene; typical procedure To a stirred solution of 1.0mmol of iodobenzene in 4mL of DMF, 1.2mmol of styrene, 2.0mmol of Et3N and 1.0mol% of TiO2@Pd nanoparticles were added and the mixture was heated on an oil bath at 140°C for 10h under inert atmosphere (N2). After completion of the reaction (as monitored by TLC), the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and the catalyst was separated by filtration. Then the mixture was extracted three times with ethyl acetate. The organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The residue was subjected to gel permeation chromatography to afford pure product. 1H NMR δ H =7.72–7.12 (m, 10H), 7.10 (s, 2H). All the products are known compounds and the spectral data and melting points were identical to those reported in the literature [18,19]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalyst The catalyst was characterized using SEM (scanning electron microscopy), EDS (energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy) and UV–vis spectroscopy. SEM and EDS were carried out for study of morphology, size and composition of nanostructures. Typical SEM and TEM images of TiO2@Pd nanoparticles are shown in Fig. 1 . As it is clear, SEM analysis was done in back scattered electron (BSE) mode. Hence, Pd nanoparticles appear as bright dots over the surface of TiO2 nanoparticles due to higher electrical conductivity. It worth to note that palladium and TiO2 nanoparticles show same diameter (about 40nm) and morphology. Therefore, in TEM image we could not distinguish between two different nanoparticles. We used EDS to determine chemical composition of our samples. In the EDS spectrum of catalyst (Fig. 2 ), peaks related to O, Ti and Pd were observed. EDS results show that Ti, Pd and oxygen concentrations are about 12%, 1.0% and 83%, respectively. The excess oxygen is due to physical absorption of oxygen from environment during sample preparation. 3.2 Optical properties In recent years, many papers have been published about surface plasmon resonance (SPR) of nanoparticles. In most of these articles the Mie theory widely used because SPR properties of nanoparticles is in good agreement with the results of this theory [20]. In this work, TiO2 nanoparticles decorated by Pd nanoparticles (TNDP) were fabricated by simple synthesis process. Commercially available dry powder TiO2 nanoparticles (Plasmachem GmbH) of pure anatase crystalline structure with 40nm particle size were dispersed in deionized (DI) water and then they were dispersed on glass substrates and dried in air. Palladium nanoparticles were overlaid on surface of TiO2 nanoparticles via a simple drop-drying process by dropping PdCl2 solution onto TiO2 nanoparticles films and drying them at room temperature. We introduce the effective medium optical constant of these thin films by comparing the experimental data and calculation results and then Mie theory and these optical constants were used for calculation of extinction cross section of dispersed TiO2 nanoparticles decorated by Pd nanoparticles in water. A typical transmission spectrum of the TNDP thin films on glass substrates is shown in Fig. 3 . In order to obtain the real part of refraction indices (n f ) of the TNDP thin films, we have used the prescription given in [21,22] where it is suggested that the following equation may be used to obtain the optical constants of low absorption thin films: (1) T = 16 n 0 n s n f 2 α e x t C 1 2 + C 2 2 α e x t 2 + 2 C 1 C 2 α e x t cos ( 4 π n f d / λ ) (2) C 1 = ( n 0 + n f ) ( n f + n s ) (3) C 2 = ( n 0 − n f ) ( n f − n s ) (4) α e x t = exp − 4 π k d λ where n f , n s , n 0 are real parts of the refraction indices of the thin film, the substrate and the air, respectively. Moreover, d is the film thickness and k is the imaginary part of the refraction index of TNDP thin films. To obtain the values of k, using the extinction coefficient equation as [23]: (5) α e x t = exp − 4 π k d λ = T 1 − R The effective real and imaginary parts of refraction indices of TNDP thin films are shown in Fig. 4 . We used these effective values as input data at Mie theory for calculation of extinction cross section of dispersed TNDP in water. Details of the Mie theory can be found in literature [24]. According to the Mie theory, the optical extinction efficiencies of spherical nanoparticles are given by the following equation. (6) C e x t = 2 x 2 ∑ n = 1 ∞ ( 2 n + 1 ) Re ( a n + b n ) x = 2 π r N m λ where λ the wavelength of the light, N m refractive index of medium, r the size parameter and a n and b n are the Mie scattering coefficients. In this theory the values of a n and b n are given by (7) a n = m ψ n ( m x ) ψ ′ n ( x ) − ψ n ( x ) ψ ′ n ( m x ) m ψ n ( m x ) ξ ′ n ( x ) − ξ n ( x ) ψ ′ n ( m x ) (8) b n = ψ n ( m x ) ψ ′ n ( x ) − m ψ n ( x ) ψ ′ n ( m x ) ψ n ( m x ) ξ ′ n ( x ) − m ξ n ( x ) ψ ′ n ( m x ) where ψ n and ξ n are Riccati-Bessel functions and m is relative refractive index of particle to medium. The result of this process is shown at Fig. 5 . It is clear that there is good agreement between calculation and experimental values of absorption spectra of TNDP dispersed in water. 3.3 Activity of TiO2@Pd nanoparticles catalyst for Heck coupling reaction The catalytic behavior of the TiO2@Pd nanoparticles was studied for Heck coupling reaction. Reaction conditions were optimized for Heck coupling reaction using bromobenzene (1.0mmol) and styrene (1.5mmol) as substrate and TiO2@Pd nanoparticles as heterogeneous catalysts in the presence of various bases under thermal conditions at 140°C (Table 1 ). Control experiments show that there is no effective reaction in the absence of catalyst or base (Table 1, entries 12 and 13). The role of the base in the mechanistic cycle is to re-activate the Pd species in solution, making it available to be recycled back into the reaction mixture [25]. Among the selected bases, Et3N acted as the most effective one (Table 1, entry 3). Due to relative insolubility effects of the inorganic bases in the organic reaction matrix, the inorganic bases recorded poor yields of product while Et3N gave the highest yield. The Heck reaction was carried out to study effect of different solvent on the % yield of product. It is reported that polar aprotic solvents tend to give the best results for Heck coupling [26]. Polar aprotic solvents are favorable for SN2 substitution reactions, believed to be taking place in the proposed mechanism hence higher product yields. As seen from Table 1, the highest activity was obtained with the most polar solvent DMF. The effect of concentration of the catalyst on the conversion is shown in Table 1. With an increase in the amount of Pd, the % yield also increases. This suggests that Pd functions as active site for the coupling reaction. Catalyst loads of 1.0mol % were typically required to achieve quantitative conversion with most substrates. The use of lower catalyst loadings resulted in incomplete reactions (entry 14). As shown in Table 1, when PdCl2 was used as the catalyst the product was obtained in low yield (Table 1, entry 11). On the other hand, PdCl2 is homogeneous which cannot be separated from the reaction mixture, while TiO2@Pd catalyst is heterogeneous and can easily be recovered and reused. With these favorable results in hand, we then used the optimal reaction conditions (catalyst (1.0mol %), aryl halide (1.0mmol), styrene (1.5mmol) and Et3N (2.0mmol)) for different substrates under thermal conditions at 140°C) for the appropriate times and the results are shown in Table 2 . To study the effects of the nature of the substituents, various products were synthesized from the reaction between different aryl halides containing both electron-releasing and electron-withdrawing groups with substituted alkenes in good to excellent yields. In addition, the coupling reaction could be efficiently carried out using aryl bromides with electron-withdrawing groups (Table 2, entries 8 and 9). However, aryl bromides containing electron-donating groups were less active and the corresponding products were obtained in moderate yields (Table 2, entries 11 and 12). To show the advantages of proposed method in comparison with other reported methods, we summarized some of results for Heck coupling reaction of styrene with bromobenzene in Table 3 , which shows that TiO2@Pd is an equally or more efficient catalyst with respect to reaction time and yield than previously reported ones. 3.4 Catalyst recyclability The recyclability of TiO2@Pd nanoparticles was further investigated because the recyclability of the heterogeneous catalyst is one of the most important issues for practical applications. The reusability of the catalyst was tested using iodobenzene and styrene as model substrates (Table 2, entry 1). After the completion of the reaction, the catalyst was recovered by filtration, followed by washing with ethanol (10mL×3). After drying, the catalyst was reused directly for the next reaction. The catalyst was recycled in order to test its activity as well as stability. The catalytic activity did not decrease considerably after four catalytic cycles, indicating that the catalyst is stable and can be regenerated for repeated use. Easy separation and reusability of the catalysts is one of the most important benefits and makes them useful for industrial applications. Homogeneous Pd complexes would not be thermally stable at high temperatures [33] since high reaction temperatures rapidly convert the homogeneous Pd(II) species into Pd colloids which readily agglomerate in the absence of stabilizing molecules. It is noteworthy that in the present work, a low loading in conjunction with a strong affinity of palladium to the TiO2 circumvents such agglomeration, thereby facilitating the recyclability of the supported catalyst. TiO2@Pd nanoparticles exhibited great stability at 140°C (Table 1). This can be attributed to thermal stability of the TiO2 support thus enhanced catalyst activity at high reaction temperatures. Another key factor to be investigated is the stability of the TiO2@Pd: leaching of active species into the reaction mixture. To address this possibility, the catalysts were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis after four cycles. In order to investigate the mechanism in our catalytic system, we conducted a hot filtration test for the Heck reaction between iodobenzene and styrene using TiO2@Pd as catalyst. After 5h (the reaction was completed in 10h), the reaction was stopped and the catalyst was separated by filtration. Then the mixture without the catalyst was allowed to continue under the same conditions for another 5h, and no noticeable reaction was observed. The Pd content of the recovered TiO2@Pd catalyst remained just about the same as the fresh catalyst, indicating that Pd leaching was negligible. The trace amount of Pd loss indicates the high affinity palladium-support. These results further confirmed the high recyclability of the catalyst, and not any leached palladium. This argument was confirmed by our ICP-AES analysis, which showed that only a very small amount of the Pd metal is removed from TiO2. The elemental analysis showed that there was less than 0.2ppm Pd in all of the Heck reaction mixtures as determined by ICP. 4 Conclusions In conclusion we have developed an efficient protocol for the preparation of TiO2@Pd nanoparticles. The catalyst was characterized by SEM, EDS and UV–vis spectroscopy and used in ligand-free Heck coupling reaction. The heterogeneous catalyst demonstrates good catalytical performance in Heck coupling reaction. This method has the advantages of high yields, elimination of ligand and homogeneous catalysts, simple methodology and easy work up. The catalyst is eco-friendly and stable because it produces little waste, and can be recovered and successively reused without the significant loss of activity. Also, the optical properties of the catalyst were also studied by Mie theory. This method has the advantages of high yields, elimination of ligand and homogeneous catalysts, simple methodology and easy work up. Interestingly, the novel catalyst could be recovered in a facile manner from the reaction mixture and recycled several times without any significant loss in activity. The catalyst was characterized by SEM, EDS and UV–vis spectroscopy. Experimental absorbance spectra compared with results from the Mie theory.
